entities.text:
Are Emergent Abilities in Large Language Models just In-Context Learning?

Spoiler: YES 🤯

Through a series of over 1,000 experiments, we provide compelling evidence:

Our results allay safety concerns regarding latent hazardous abilities.

A🧵👇

user.name: UKP Lab
user.description: The Ubiquitous Knowledge Processing Lab researches Natural Language Processing, Text Mining, eLearning, and Digital Humanities · @CS_TUDarmstadt · @TUDarmstadt

entities.text:
et al. that Large Language Models have Emergent Abilities.

The »unpredictable emergence« of such a large number of abilities, it has been claimed, is indicative of the possibility that there are latent hazardous abilities. (2/)

user.name: UKP Lab
user.description: The Ubiquitous Knowledge Processing Lab researches Natural Language Processing, Text Mining, eLearning, and Digital Humanities · @CS_TUDarmstadt · @TUDarmstadt

entities.text:
We perform the first set of experiments to test models without in-context learning and show that in this setting only 2 of the 22 tasks originally reported to be emergent are »truly emergent«.

Of these 2, one tests linguistic skills and the other tests memory.

No »Reasoning« 🤔

user.name: UKP Lab
user.description: The Ubiquitous Knowledge Processing Lab researches Natural Language Processing, Text Mining, eLearning, and Digital Humanities · @CS_TUDarmstadt · @TUDarmstadt

entities.text:
Does Instruction Tuning (including on Code) lead to »reasoning«?

Turns out: No 🚫

Without in-context learning the tasks solvable by T5 770M and GPT-3 175B are comparable! 🤯😯 (4/)

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Text from paper: 

It has been argued that the unpredictability associated with such emergent abilities underscores the possibility that these models might harbour latent hazardous abilities that manifest unexpectedly.

It’s important to emphasise that the development of explicit linguistic proficiencies does not pose inherent risks of this nature. The same can be said for the capacity to efficiently handle information retrieval tasks. The real concern lies in potential harmful capabilities relating to functional linguistic abilities, especially reasoning and planning (Hoffmann, 2022), which we refer to in this work as latent hazardous abilities. However, it must be emphasised that this does not include other dangers posed through the misuse of these models, such as
the use of LLMs to generate fake news.

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
I think not. BigBench is specifically designed to be able to test more than just memory. 

Our central claim is that in-context learning provides explicit clues to how to solve a problem. So we cannot use in-context learning to claim inherent abilities.

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
I would would rephrase our work as being a test for *if there is anything (including reasoning) more than in-context learning*. 

Whatever that more might be, we show that models are unlikely to be able to do it.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Text from paper: 

The distinction between the ability to follow instructions and the inherent ability to solve a problem is a subtle but important one. Simple following
of instructions without applying reasoning abilities
produces output that is consistent with the instructions, but might not make sense on a logical or
commonsense basis. This is reflected in the wellknown phenomenon of hallucination, in which an
LLM produces fluent, but factually incorrect output
(Bang et al., 2023; Shen et al., 2023; Thorp, 2023).
The ability to follow instructions does not imply
having reasoning abilities, and more importantly, it
does not imply the possibility of latent hazardous
abilities that could be dangerous (Hoffmann, 2022).

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
From paper: 

Artificial neural models have, for some time, exhibited the ability to achieve significant success on
specific tasks when trained on those tasks (Devlin
et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2019). PLMs in particular have demonstrated this even in the few-shot
setting (Hofer et al., 2018; Radford et al., 2019;
Brown et al., 2020; Gao et al., 2020). Such performance after training on a task is not considered
“emergent”, precisely because models are trained
on that very task. Indeed, the fact that LLMs are not
trained on the tasks used in evaluating their emergent abilities is central to identifying abilities which
are truly emergent. The assertion that achieving
satisfactory performance on a given task signifies
the emergence of associated ‘abilities’ hinges on
the condition that models are not explicitly trained
for that specific task. Alternatively, it would suggest that a model possesses the expressive power
required to undergo training for the said task. Only
if an LLM has not bee

entities.text:
I read a paper (for the first time in months.....) but have been struggling with writing a clean + convincing thread, so instead I'll dump my high level thoughts in 4 tweets.

tl;dr: Paper is v cool, but doesn't rule out capability jumps like Twitter seems to think it does.

user.name: Aidan Clark
user.description:
Research @OpenAI.
Ex: @DeepMind, @BerkeleyDAGRS
Hae sententiae verbaque mihi soli sunt

entities.text:
1)
The paper defines "ability" as 0shot base model perf, but it's unclear why this is correct & buried in Fig. 9 is data showing base-model fewshot shows emergence. I think much more work is needed to convince me that few-shot/IF performance is somehow not indicative of ability.

user.name: Aidan Clark
user.description:
Research @OpenAI.
Ex: @DeepMind, @BerkeleyDAGRS
Hae sententiae verbaque mihi soli sunt

entities.text:
2)
Of key relevance to emergence is the "unexpected" part, but the jump between 7B and 175B is just too great. I acknowledge the authors didn't have the access or resources to address this, but it's impossible to make a claim about predictability of emergence on this scale.

user.name: Aidan Clark
user.description:
Research @OpenAI.
Ex: @DeepMind, @BerkeleyDAGRS
Hae sententiae verbaque mihi soli sunt

entities.text:
3) 
The paper convincingly shows many emergent abilities disappear when 0-shot eval-ing the base model - a great result! But I don't think there is conclusive evidence towards the high-level claim is that emergence is just ICL + ICL doesn't have inherent emergence risks.

user.name: Aidan Clark
user.description:
Research @OpenAI.
Ex: @DeepMind, @BerkeleyDAGRS
Hae sententiae verbaque mihi soli sunt

1700666106153939378.location: fine-tuning, in-context learning, and other prompting techniques

entities.text:
4) 
I'd like to think I'm relatively unbiased -- in that I actually buy these claims and in particular, I actually don't really believe in emergence and think grokking phenoms are probably complex acceptance criteria on top of smoothly-scaling components.

user.name: Aidan Clark
user.description:
Research @OpenAI.
Ex: @DeepMind, @BerkeleyDAGRS
Hae sententiae verbaque mihi soli sunt

entities.text: Final addendum: Don't want to sound too negative! I enjoyed reading the paper and think the authors did a great job, I just don't think the Twitter takeaway of "there is no concern!" is warranted.

user.name: Guy Dar
user.description: #NLProc Researcher | #AI #NLProc #interpretability | If I've seen further, I was probably standing on a stool

entities.text:
Thank you for taking the time to go through our paper. 

I'm afraid I must disagree with you on this - we *do* rule out "emergent abilities" of the kind that are likely to result in latent hazardous abilities. 

More on your tweets, in replies below ⬇️

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Extract from paper: 

The distinction between the ability to follow instructions and the inherent ability to solve a problem is a subtle but important one. Simple following
of instructions without applying reasoning abilities
produces output that is consistent with the instructions, but might not make sense on a logical or
commonsense basis. This is reflected in the wellknown phenomenon of hallucination, in which an
LLM produces fluent, but factually incorrect output
(Bang et al., 2023; Shen et al., 2023; Thorp, 2023).
The ability to follow instructions does not imply
having reasoning abilities, and more importantly, it
does not imply the possibility of latent hazardous
abilities that could be dangerous (Hoffmann, 2022).
Attributing these capabilities to a combination
of memory and in-context learning and the more
general ability of these models to generate the most
statistically likely next token, can help explain the
abilities and the behaviour of LLMs.

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text: I think there might be some misunderstanding-The definition of "emergent abilities" we us is that introduced

et al 2022

Pages 2 3 and 4 detail why any perf gains in settings other than 0shot +base model *cannot* be emergent

will be good to hear why you think it does?

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Extract from paper: 

 The assertion that achieving
satisfactory performance on a given task signifies
the emergence of associated ‘abilities’ hinges on
the condition that models are not explicitly trained
for that specific task. Alternatively, it would suggest that a model possesses the expressive power
required to undergo training for the said task. Only
if an LLM has not been trained on a task that it
performed well on can the claim be made that the
model inherently possesses the ability necessary for
that task. Otherwise, the ability must be learned,
i.e. through explicit training or in-context learning,
in which case it is no longer an ability of the model
per se, and is no longer unpredictable. In other
words, the ability is not emergent.

That's a very interesting take. As above, would really like to hear why. 

ICL allows models to follow instructions and - while that is incredible - cannot lead to any emergent risks. 

ICL allows for an explicit way to control models.

Extract from Sec 5.5.1 in paper:

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Extract from paper: 

 Ultimately, this absence of evidence
for emergence represents a significant step towards
instilling trust in language models and leveraging
their abilities with confidence, as it is indicative
of the complete lack of latent hazardous abilities
in LLMs, in addition to being controllable by the
user.

The distinction between the ability to follow instructions and the inherent ability to solve a problem is a subtle but important one. Simple following
of instructions without applying reasoning abilities
produces output that is consistent with the instructions, but might not make sense on a logical or
commonsense basis. This is reflected in the wellknown phenomenon of hallucination, in which an
LLM produces fluent, but factually incorrect output
(Bang et al., 2023; Shen et al., 2023; Thorp, 2023).
The ability to follow instructions does not imply
having reasoning abilities, and more importantly, it
does not imply the possibility of latent hazardous
abilities that could be dangerous (Hoffmann, 2022)

user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
Similarly, how do we test if a model has an "ability"?

From the paper: To evaluate the extent to which a model has access to social situations, we test the model's ability to "solve" (>baseline) a task that tests this (eg, socialIQA).

*without training on socialIQa data*

3/n

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Extract from paper: 

As an example, the emergent ability
to understand social situations in LLMs is inferred
from LLMs’ performing well above the random
baseline on the Social IQa (Sap et al., 2019) task.
This task serves to evaluate models’ emotional and
social intelligence and includes questions such as:
Question: Carson was excited to wake
up to attend school. Why did he do this?
Options: “Take the big test”, “Go to bed
early”, “Just say hello to friends”

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
If we trained on socialIQA (or similar) data before testing the model, also on socialIQa data, that's uninteresting.

We cannot say that it has the associated "ability". It only has the expressive power to solve it.

(1.3 from paper)

4/n

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Extract from paper: 

k. Indeed, the fact that LLMs are not
trained on the tasks used in evaluating their emergent abilities is central to identifying abilities which
are truly emergent. The assertion that achieving
satisfactory performance on a given task signifies
the emergence of associated ‘abilities’ hinges on
the condition that models are not explicitly trained
for that specific task. Alternatively, it would suggest that a model possesses the expressive power
required to undergo training for the said task. Only
if an LLM has not been trained on a task that it
performed well on can the claim be made that the
model inherently possesses the ability necessary for
that task. Otherwise, the ability must be learned,
i.e. through explicit training or in-context learning,
in which case it is no longer an ability of the model
per se, and is no longer unpredictable. In other
words, the ability is not emergent.

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
Now, let's consider in-context learning: It allows us to induce a model to perform a task based on a "few" examples

The model will perform the task even if we use semantically unrelated labels (Wei et al., 2023)

This implies "learning" from examples (see attached extract)

5/n

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Extract from paper: 

In-context learning is the ability of LLMs to
perform a task with only a minimal set of exemplars presented within the context of the input
prompt (Brown et al., 2020; Dong et al., 2022;
Liu et al., 2023). While this ability of LLMs has
been known for some time (Kojima et al., 2022;
Srivastava et al., 2022), recent work has shown that
LLMs are capable of in-context learning even in
cases where labels are flipped or semantically unrelated, as in the case of flipped labels for sentiment
analysis (Wei et al., 2023). Crucially, it should be
noted that the capacity to excel in a flipped labelling
task, such as attributing a negative sentiment to sentences labelled as positive and vice versa, inherently relies on in-context learning. Without this,
the model would be unable to adapt its sentence
labelling accordingly

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
So: 

1 --> ICL is *like* training (the flipped labels and the recent theory we have support this idea) - Section 2 of paper.

2 --> to test abilities, we must not "train".

Therefore, we must not use ICL to evaluate "abilities"

6/n

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
What of Instruction-Tuning (IT)?

Notice that IT data has explicit mappings between instructions and exemplars. Given this, the simplest explanation is that IT triggers ICL. 

If we adapt this framing/theory, we can explain a lot of things: 

a) Hallucinations cont ... 

7/n

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
From paper: 

Illustration of IT data has explicit mappings between instructions and exemplars. Given this, the simplest explanation is that IT triggers ICL.

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
... cont

b) prompting techniques that now work,
c) CoT prompting

Now, let's make a prediction: We predict that if we compare the tasks solvable by ICL without IT and IT without ICL, they will overlap significantly.

Turns out .. they do. Even when we compare T5 & GPT!

8/n

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Illustration from paper showing task overlap (fig 7)

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
Now, we can say that nothing contradicts this simple explanation that IT triggers ICL.

By invoking Occam's razor, we conclude that we do not need any more complex explanations for IT capabilities (including reasoning) -- invoking ICL will do.

9/n

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
So, as before:

1 --> ICL is *like* training

2 --> to test abilities, we must not "train".

3 --> IT most likely triggers ICL.

Therefore, we must not use either ICL or IT  to evaluate "abilities"

10/n

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
About: "you put in effort to find this correct phrasing, and all of the sudden the model can do something you previously said it couldn't"

Yes ... BUT:

In ML, we increase the # of layers to solve one prob and it can now solve other problems it previously could not!

11/n

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
This does not mean it has the abilities required to solve those problems because such models still need to be trained on each of those models.

12/n

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
ICL itself isn't unpredictable, because it "grows" with scale.

So we can completely predict what models can do: i.e., what we tell them to do.

At scale, we can tell models to perform tasks that require more expressive power - but still must clearly instruct them how.

13/n

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
So these are amazing & powerful models that can do a lot of what we tell them to. 

Scaling up will increase what they are capable of doing **when explicitly instructed to do so**

They will not have latent hazardous abilities.

They are safe. 

n/n

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Text from: https://openreview.net/pdf?id=yzkSU5zdwD 

As a broad concept, emergence is often used informally and can be reasonably interpreted in many different ways. In this paper, we will consider a focused definition of emergent abilities of large language models:

An ability is emergent if it is not present in smaller models but is present in larger models.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Text from Wei et al., 2022: Emergent abilities would not have been directly predicted by extrapolating a scaling law (i.e. consistent
performance improvements) from small-scale models. When visualized via a scaling curve (x-axis: model
scale, y-axis: performance), emergent abilities show a clear pattern—performance is near-random until a
certain critical threshold of scale is reached, after which performance increases to substantially above random.
This qualitative change is also known as a phase transition—a dramatic change in overall behavior that would
not have been foreseen by examining smaller-scale systems (Huberman & Hogg, 1987).

user.name: Phi
user.description: Researcher Focus on LLMs.

entities.text:
Last week in AI was intensive. To say the least. 😅 Here is some interesting work that spiked my attention:

*

<- open-interpreter let's you run powerful LLMs directly from your terminal. Cross-platform.

*

<- "One Wide Feedforward is All You Need", a new paper from, wait for it, Apple? I'm not sure if my eyes are playing tricks on me. I saw 0 cool papers, well 0 papers in general coming from Apple. In this one they experiment with the fundamental transformer architecture: they remove FFN from the decoder and they share a single FFN in the encoder. FFN takes a ton of params so this is a big saving. Outperforms original transformer - at a small scale, let's see whether this works.

*

<- "Are Emergent Abilities in Large Language Models just In-Context Learning?" Through an extensive series of over 1,000 experiments they conclude that the answer is yes. In-context is one of the main reasons why LLMs work.

* TIMES 100 misses out on some of the most important names in AI :P

*

<- "YaRN: Efficient Context Window Extension of Large Language Model" YaRN (Yet another RoPE extensioN method), a compute-efficient method to extend the context window of LLMs, requiring 10x less tokens and 2.5x less training

steps than previous methods. Super exciting work I'll have the authors giving a talk in my Discord server soon, keep an eye out for this one! :)

*

<- "this pr adds a third party backend for triton that works on AMD". Change is coming, AMD is coming. :) A bit more context for those new to AI: NVIDIA has been dominating the field with its hardware but esp. with its software stack (CUDA). AMD now added a support (backend) for Triton which is a layer above CUDA/ROCM (AMD's stack) that is being adopted in PyTorch and across the industry.

* Talking about NVIDIA: I won't lie I love that company. I was on a pre-brief meeting  for their new TensorRT improvements and it's super interesting. They've done a ton of optimization work, Llama-2 gets ~2x speed up on H100 (we're talking about *inference* here). Check out their blog:

<- "Large Language Models as Optimizers". Exciting new work from my ex colleagues at Google DeepMind. Tehy introduce OPRO method. Optimization task is specified in natural lang. They automatically come up with much more powerful prompts like "Take a deep breath and work on this problem step-by-step". Yes this actually boosts the model performance, you read it well :)

Part 1. As I said there was a ton of exciting work, Part 2. coming a bit later today :)

Cool paper. 
Few-shot learning helps a base model to know what task it is solving. (It helps even if labels are incorrect and if the few-shot examples are for a different but related task see the "ICIL paper"

). 
I can imagine just giving 2 few-shot examples of easy cases would help a base model to perform on much harder cases. Thus, the model's ability is not just "in-context learning", but would still involve reasoning. (I'm not sure how else it could be explained). What do you think?

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
Emergent abilities in LLMs!

Have you ever wondered how LLMs acquire their superpowers❓

About a year ago, a paper was published discussing an unpredictable phenomenon known as emergent abilities in LLMs.

Emergence is when small, incremental changes or additions to a system lead to new, unexpected behaviors that weren't present before.

In recent years, there have been significant efforts to scale up LMs into Large Language Models (LLMs).

The process of scaling involves training larger models on more data with increased computational power.

Firstly this leads to predictable and consistent improvement in the performance of the language model.

But then when scaling hits a certain threshold, magic happens & new capabilities appear at random, in unpredictable ways.

These new (emergent) capabilities include performing complex, arithmetic, summarizing passages, answering questions, one/few shot learning by juts providing a simple natural language prompt.

For example, I provide the following prompt to GPT-4:

Prompt: Guess the movies based on following emojis:
🛳️🌊❤️🧊🎶🔥🚢💔👫💑

GPT4: The movie based on those emojis is "Titanic." The emojis represent the ship, the ocean, love, iceberg, music from the iconic scene, fire from the boiler room, the sinking ship, heartbreak, and the central couple (Jack and Rose).

You don't explicitly train LLMs  to get this smart, these abilities are emergent.

So, why it's important to study these emergent properties❓

1. Unpredictability: Emergent abilities can't be foreseen by merely scaling up smaller models. Recognizing this unpredictability helps us better anticipate model behavior.

2. Future Capabilities: Emergent abilities hint at untapped potential in even larger models, suggesting more advanced capabilities might be on the horizon.

3. Training Insights: Understanding emergence can guide refinements in training methods and model architectures, potentially unlocking abilities at smaller scales.

4. Risk Management: Alongside emergent abilities come emergent risks. By studying these, we can proactively address and mitigate potential pitfalls.

5. Broader AI Implications: Emergence insights in language models can inform research in other AI domains, enhancing our grasp of complex AI behaviors.

6. Decision Making: For AI practitioners, a clear understanding of emergent properties aids in choosing the right models and setting appropriate expectations.

Conclusion:

Understanding emergent properties offers a clearer roadmap for AI development, application, and research.

References:
-

That's a wrap!

I get this all the time. People ask me how I am so sure AGI will lead to dystopia or extinction.

I agree with most of that, but it is even worse.  We have no way of understanding whether any specific state of that evolutionary explosion of intelligence is either stable or self-perpetuating.   Does the AI kill us off - either because we are irrelevant or because we present an obstacle to optimal growth of its intelligence - only to then evolve further and decide that its goals are not obtainable and it has no reason to exist further?

I am not trying to deduce any specific end point.   Rather, it seems to me that the entire process is potentially unstable and does not converge into any stable state that continues on.  So just as serious as the death of humanity would be extinguishing all forms of consciousness.

user.name: Derek Chen
user.description: Research scientist in conversational AI. Building @soleda_ai through scalable data generation.  Prev: @columbianlp, @asapp, @UW, @stanfordnlp, @UCBerkeley

entities.text: Btw, there are still many issues: lack of compositionality, questionable theory of mind, weak reasoning ability, poor meta-cognition, breaks on non-English queries (when those same queries work in English). All explainable if we assume LLMs learn by data alone.

user.name: Derek Chen
user.description: Research scientist in conversational AI. Building @soleda_ai through scalable data generation.  Prev: @columbianlp, @asapp, @UW, @stanfordnlp, @UCBerkeley

entities.text: Also, small models (~13B) fine-tuned with specialized data consistently outperform ChatGPT. (Most papers written before GPT-4o released). Public data simply doesn't contain examples of specialized knowledge and complex planning.

user.name: Derek Chen
user.description: Research scientist in conversational AI. Building @soleda_ai through scalable data generation.  Prev: @columbianlp, @asapp, @UW, @stanfordnlp, @UCBerkeley

entities.text: To be clear, I strongly believe in an improvement for the next round of models.  But we're looking at an S-shaped curve here, not an exponential growth.

entities.text:
To sum up what LLMs are really doing for/with us, I submit we can do no better than the old Engelbart dictum:

'By "augmenting human intellect" we mean increasing the capability of a man to approach a complex problem situation, to gain comprehension to suit his particular needs, and to derive solutions to problems… whether the problem situation exists for twenty minutes or twenty years. We do not speak of isolated clever tricks that help in particular situations. We refer to a way of life in an integrated domain where hunches, cut-and-try, intangibles, and the human "feel for a situation" usefully co-exist with powerful concepts, streamlined terminology and notation, sophisticated methods, and high-powered electronic aids.'

user.name: Harish Tayyar Madabushi
user.description: Lecturer (~Assistant Professor) in Artificial Intelligence. Work on Deep Learning for #NLProc and Deep Contextual Meaning Representations

entities.text:
LLMs Can Perceive Reality

To be a very good next-word predictor, you need a world model of sorts.

LLMs have a multi-dimensional latent space that is akin to a simulated version of reality.

This simulated version is developed as training progresses, enabling the LLM to respond "intelligently" to puzzles, coding, and other reasoning questions.

There is a lot of debate on whether LLMs can reason, and we have consistently found that they do so in the sense that they can accurately solve reasoning and programming challenges.

However, there is still much room for improvement, and we will see more performant models in the coming months. 

The more we understand how these LLMS work, the more we are likely to develop better techniques that improve coding and reasoning.

So yes, there is room to grow beyond GPT-4 and Sonnet 3.5 class, and it's not going to be long before we see a significant leap like we saw with 3.5 🚀🚀

entities.text:
Language is definitely a necessary component for high level abstract reasoning.

We use all the 5 senses to map our reality and language is one of the best tool we have to navigate it.

So language alone might still give us an incomplete map of the world but it’s still a good approximation.

I wonder if, at some point, the approximation will be so good that LLMs will be able to fake a complete understanding of reality (like they already seem to be doing for most mundane tasks).

But I’m sure that large multi modal models have a better chance at AGI.

entities.text:
Large Language Models are not "intelligent."

More importantly, it's abundantly clear we won't get to general intelligence by simply scaling these models.

We need new breakthroughs. We need a different architecture.

(Those waiting for GPT-5 to be AGI will probably be disappointed.)

Attached is yet another paper dunking on the hype.

An important idea from the paper:

"Our findings suggest that purported emergent abilities are not truly emergent, but result from a combination of in-context learning, model memory, and linguistic knowledge."

In English: The intelligence you see is coming from memorization and the person writing the prompt.

Another one:

"The ability to follow instructions does not imply having reasoning abilities, and more importantly, it does not imply the possibility of latent, potentially-dangerous abilities."

Yeah, we knew that already: LLMs are not going to destroy the world.

No True Emergence: 

What seems like new abilities in LLMs is actually a mix of memorization, in-context learning, and linguistic tricks.

No Real Intelligence:

In short, scaling current models won't lead to AGI; we need new approaches.

entities.text:
büyük dil modellerinde (llm) görülen ve "emergent abilities" (beklenmedik şekilde ortaya çıkan yetenekler) olarak adlandırılan bazı özelliklerin, aslında sadece "in-context learning" (bağlamdan öğrenme) olup olmadığını araştıran yeni bir çalışma yapılmış.

"in-context learning", kısaca llm'lerin birkaç örnek görerek bir görevi öğrenip uygulayabilme yeteneği diyebiliriz.

örneğin, modele "elma: meyve, köpek: hayvan, masa: ?" şeklinde bir prompt verildiğinde, model bağlamdan öğrenerek "eşya" cevabını verebilir.

"emergent abilities" konusu, "ai safety" tartışmalarında önemli bir yer tutuyor. bazı araştırmacılar, llm'lerin beklenmedik yetenekler geliştirerek potansiyel tehlike oluşturabileceğini savunurken, diğerleri bu yeteneklerin abartıldığını düşünüyor. 

örneğin, bir taraf llm'lerin karmaşık akıl yürütme becerileri geliştirdiğini iddia ederken, diğer taraf bunun sadece veri tekrarı olduğunu söylüyor.

araştırmacılar, 20 farklı modeli 22 görev üzerinde test ederek, "emergent abilities" olarak tanımlanan yeteneklerin çoğunun aslında "in-context learning" sayesinde ortaya çıktığını göstermişler. 

yani, modeller gerçekten yeni yetenekler geliştirmek yerine, verilen örneklerden öğreniyorlar.

çalışmanın sonuçları, llm'lerin düşünüldüğü kadar "akıllı" olmadığını ve potansiyel tehlikelerinin abartıldığını gösteriyor. modeller, temel dilbilgisi ve bilgi hatırlama gibi basit görevlerde başarılı olurken, karmaşık akıl yürütme gerektiren görevlerde zorlanıyorlar.

bu bulgular, llm'lerin daha etkili kullanımı için önemli ipuçları sunuyor. kullanıcıların, modellerden daha iyi sonuçlar almak için daha detaylı prompt ve örnekler vermesi gerekiyor. 

ayrıca, "ai safety" konusundaki endişelerin bir kısmının yersiz olabileceğini gösteriyor.

1.title: fine-tuning, in-context learning, and other prompting techniques

4.title: emergence in gpt in the absence of in-context learning

author: <1824139554275856764> points to prior work by Jason Wei that introduced the concept of "emergent abilities" in Large Language Models, which this paper aims to debunk by providing an alternative explanation based on in-context learning and other factors.
related work: <1724026416168100059> highlighted the discussion paper "Capabilities and risks from frontier AI" [[assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/65395aba…]] from the 2023 AI Safety Summit, which quotes the author's own research. This directly relates to the given paper by focusing on the evaluation and implications of LLM capabilities, particularly regarding emergent abilities and potential risks.

<1824180551726809598> mentioned YAGO [[yago-knowledge.org/downloads/yago…]] as a simplified knowledge base derived from Wikidata. This could complement the given paper by offering a potential resource for grounding LLMs and enhancing their world models, which might indirectly influence the development of emergent abilities.
general: <1824530145170034793> and <1825553433426001929> linked to "Emergent Abilities of Large Language Models" by Lu et al. (2023) [[arxiv.org/abs/2309.01809]], which likely provides a contrasting perspective on the emergence of abilities in LLMs, as the given paper argues against true emergence.

related work: <1824847624748278016> shared a paper [[arxiv.org/abs/2309.01809]] that supports the current paper's argument by providing evidence against the existence of emergent abilities in LLMs.

<1715610895458414878> mentioned a study [[arxiv.org/abs/2304.15004]] that questions the concept of emergent abilities, suggesting they may be a result of using specific evaluation metrics, which complements the current paper's focus on ICL as an alternative explanation.

<1823382602809757732> provided links to several papers on ICL ([[arxiv.org/abs/2402.12530]], [[arxiv.org/abs/2309.01809]], [[arxiv.org/abs/2406.04216]]) which directly relate to the current paper's claim that ICL plays a significant role in the observed "emergent abilities."

abstract: <1699648809465467118> questions the paper's claim that reasoning is not an emergent ability in LLMs, highlighting the ambiguity of the term 'reasoning'.
<1699746587348459647> clarifies that the paper posits in-context learning as a sufficient explanation for LLM capabilities, obviating the need to invoke 'reasoning'.
<1700250886734586069> supports the paper's view of LLMs as 'Context Processing Machines' whose abilities are rooted in in-context learning.
Other discussions revolve around the predictability of LLMs based on in-context learning and the significance of this research for understanding LLM capabilities.
introduction, motivation and context: <1824548742571434486> argues that emergent properties in LLMs are real and significant, even if they can be explained by simpler mechanisms like in-context learning, drawing an analogy to a jet's ability to fly being explained by Newton's third law.
significance for applications and safety: <1700467194029547544> questioned how the conclusion that emergent abilities stem from a mesa-optimizer implies increased safety. <1700481368046604390> clarified the term's usefulness but cautioned against applying it to in-context learning. <1700951919223541893> argued that a mesa-optimizer implies safety because it optimizes for specified objectives, similar to fine-tuning.
abilities vs. techniques: <1700879349312806928> found the paper's evidence compelling, viewing ICL's emergence as a paradigm shift in NLP. <1700947207749337133> agreed but questioned its safety implications.
<1699960877259137207> suggested that in-context learning and reasoning may not be mutually exclusive, potentially exhibiting a passive relationship.
Other users discussed the nature of ICL and its potential as a flexible learner given sufficient data across various modalities.
conclusions and implications: <1824574149244735646> points out that LLMs don't grow or learn like humans, but are carefully curated.
<1824539936068080074> shares a lawyer's perspective, noting LLMs' inability to create new arguments for atypical cases, relying instead on trained data.
<1825132663315038263> emphasizes that following instructions doesn't equate to reasoning, reflecting the paper's point about LLMs' lack of true reasoning abilities.

abstract: <1824776142412517380> points out a seeming contradiction in the paper's abstract: it claims emergent abilities aren't emergent, yet describes emergence. <1825234594389794876> clarifies, pointing to a specific section in the paper and offering further reading.
introduction, motivation and context: <1824856535358677346> questions if LLMs can create something truly new beyond combinations of training data. <1824863550147641775> argues that humans' capacity for technological and cultural development demonstrates an ability beyond statistical algorithms.

<1699639747482956257> asks if the absence of reasoning in LLMs safeguards jobs requiring reasoning. <1699665120027152637> suggests that reasoning might involve testing and rejecting false completions, while <1699786112628310162> rephrases the paper's focus as investigating if there's more to LLMs than in-context learning.
abilities vs. techniques: <1699648201832161634> questioned whether in-context learning implies a lack of reasoning, arguing that adapting to examples requires abstract thinking. <1699786950016987446> responded by referencing the paper's discussion on training and social understanding.

<1700908698544070912> asked why the paper claims abilities aren't emergent if they appear with in-context prompts. <1701331981894578350> clarified that ICL's predictability makes it non-emergent, unlike unpredictable, potentially hazardous abilities.

<1699656989952057566> asked about the paper's claim regarding GPT-3's performance. <1699657674885898647> replied that GPT-3's better performance is attributed to memorization, not reasoning. <1699785597383311553> added that in-context learning provides explicit problem-solving clues, not inherent abilities.
models: <1702298223015067947> questioned the authors' choice of not using EleutherAI's Pythia models and the stated unavailability of PaLM, pointing to the public API for PaLM 2 Gecko and Bison models.
emergence in gpt in the absence of in-co: <1699643493369442728> questioned the paper's conclusions on emergent abilities due to similar performance between models with and without in-context learning/instruction tuning.
<1699743480275141058> clarified that the comparison should be with the non-instruction-tuned zero-shot GPT-3, which only excels in two tasks.
<1699751191826042898> asked about the performance gap between zero-shot and few-shot/ICL, prompting discussion on instruction tuning's role in ICL.
The remaining conversation clarified model details and incorporated feedback for the paper's improvement.
conclusions and implications: <1824520750554042830> defines reasoning as the ability to find answers or paths towards a goal, arguing that LLMs are reactively intelligent but lack active problem-solving skills.
<1824565055951712647> contends that LLMs lack reasoning abilities as they cannot apply algorithms like Dijkstra's shortest path to large graphs, unlike humans.
While <1824855243059773522> suggests interface limitations affect LLMs' performance, <1824855964887011725> emphasizes the context window limitation restricts LLMs' reasoning compared to humans.
instruction-ttuning as implicit: <1700947063951737194> argues that ICL, being an explicit control mechanism, cannot lead to emergent risks. <1700970136122040823> counters that clever prompting might unlock unexpected model capabilities, resembling emergence.

<1701013317228339625> explains that ICL is analogous to training, and true abilities should be tested without prior training on the task.  <1701014375883227636> uses the example of SocialIQA to illustrate this point.
<1701026852104720885> highlights a terminological difference, noting that the paper's definition of "ability" might not align with the common understanding, where few-shot success implies ability.

Other discussions revolve around the interplay of ICL and instruction tuning, with users like <1701140559015051426> questioning whether cross-task transfer after instruction tuning constitutes emergence.

experimental setup: <1701806872091631990> suggests that the only explanation for the observed emergent abilities is that exam/test data leaked into GPT-4's training data.
conclusions and implications: <1700972851455795593> questioned the authors' definition of 'ability' and the dismissal of few-shot prompting as a valid test.
<1701129955621646679> argued that the paper's premise doesn't test for latent abilities but rather for observables in untuned LLMs, which aren't meant for direct use.

Other discussions touched upon the link between instruction tuning, ICL, and the emergence of potentially hazardous abilities, with <1700946778470649924> arguing against the emergence of such abilities.

Perspective.abstract: The authors argue that emergent abilities in large language models are not truly emergent but rather a combination of in-context learning, model memory, and linguistic knowledge. They support this claim with over 1000 experiments, suggesting that LLMs' capabilities might be overestimated.
Perspective.introduction, motivation and context: The authors define emergent abilities in Large Language Models (LLMs) as abilities that are absent in smaller models but present in larger ones, enabling them to perform above random chance on tasks without explicit training.  They provide the example of social situation understanding, where LLMs perform well on tests like Social IQA without specific training on that task.
Perspective.significance for applications and safety: The authors discuss the implications of emergent abilities in LLMs, distinguishing between formal and functional linguistic abilities. They argue that while the emergence of functional abilities raises safety concerns due to unpredictability, the evidence from current LLMs doesn't support the narrative of an existential threat.
Perspective.abilities vs. techniques: The authors differentiate between emergent abilities and prompting techniques like in-context learning (ICL) and instruction-tuning in LLMs.  They observe that both emerge at similar scales, but prompting techniques are also present in smaller models, making them predictable and less of a safety concern compared to emergent abilities. The study investigates the extent of emergent abilities without prompting techniques.
Perspective.conclusions and implications: The authors argue that large language models (LLMs) primarily rely on in-context learning (ICL) rather than exhibiting true emergent abilities. They highlight that LLMs excel at following instructions but often lack reasoning skills, leading to "hallucinations" where they produce fluent but factually incorrect outputs.

Q&A.abstract: The authors investigate whether "emergent abilities" in large language models are truly novel capabilities or simply a result of existing competencies like in-context learning and model memory. They argue that these abilities are not emergent, but rather a combination of pre-existing factors.
Q&A.introduction, motivation and context: The authors discuss the emergent abilities of Large Language Models (LLMs), contrasting them with formal and functional linguistic abilities. While LLMs excel at formal linguistic abilities, their emergent abilities, like performing well on tasks requiring reasoning without explicit training, are a newer phenomenon and a key focus of the paper.  These emergent abilities are defined as capabilities absent in smaller models but present in larger ones.
Q&A.abilities vs. techniques: The authors argue that in-context learning (ICL), where LLMs learn from examples within the prompt, is not an emergent ability because it scales predictably with model size.  They contrast this with true emergent abilities, which are unpredictable and potentially hazardous.  The authors question the extent of emergent abilities without prompting techniques like ICL.
Q&A.models: The authors experimented with four model families (GPT, T5, Falcon, and LLaMA) at different scales to investigate the relationship between model scale and emergent abilities. They considered both base and instruction-tuned versions of the models.
Q&A.emergence in gpt in the absence of in-co: The authors investigated emergent abilities in large language models, focusing on non-instruction-tuned GPT models in zero-shot settings to exclude the influence of in-context learning. They found only two tasks exhibiting emergent abilities, neither of which involves complex reasoning.
Q&A.conclusions and implications: The authors argue that emergent abilities in LLMs are primarily due to in-context learning (ICL) rather than true reasoning. They emphasize that instruction-tuned LLMs excel at following instructions but often lack logical or commonsense reasoning, leading to hallucinations. This aligns with the observation that LLMs struggle with tasks requiring reasoning beyond their training data.
Q&A.instruction-ttuning as implicit: The authors argue that emergent abilities in large language models are not truly emergent but rather a product of in-context learning, model memory, and linguistic knowledge. They conducted over 1000 experiments to support this claim, suggesting that model capabilities are often overestimated.

Critique.experimental setup: The authors investigated emergent abilities in large language models without in-context learning, experimenting with 20 models across 22 tasks using various evaluation metrics and bias tests.
Critique.conclusions and implications: The authors argue that emergent abilities in LLMs are a result of in-context learning (ICL), and instruction tuning leads to implicit ICL rather than new abilities. They distinguish between following instructions and reasoning, highlighting that instruction-following without reasoning can lead to hallucinations.  This suggests that observed abilities might not indicate potentially dangerous latent abilities.
